For five years, John has been running a general store on Duport Road, which is near the Red Light Market in Paynesville, Liberia.  He says he sells goods that customers demand, which keeps them returning. One of the challenges he faces is that there are many competitors in the market.

John plans to use his 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more provisions. His goal is to improve the living standard of his family members.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, John is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase general store provisions.

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn D., from the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Neuva Vizcaya, is 34 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jenelyn has sold charcoal and firewood in the local community for over 10 years, earning approximately 7500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Jenelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan, her eighth, of 15000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. Jenelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partnesr to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Elia Maria

texts.es: Elia Maria tiene 69 años, su actividad económica es la venta y elaboración de tortillas. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio, pues siempre ha presentado mucho interés en mejorar los gastos de su familia. Ella dio inicio por iniciativa propia, pues con mucho empeño ha demostrado ser una excelente cliente. Ella está solicitando este crédito para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de materia prima como maíz, cal y comal. Su deseo es mejorar su vivienda, pues así podrá ofrecerles a sus hijas un porvenir.
texts.en:
Elia Maria is 69 years old, and her main economic activity is the production and sale of tortillas. She has been in this business for more than 6 years, as she has always had a keen interest in improving her family's economic situation. She launched her business on her own initiative, and with a lot of effort she has demonstrated herself to be an excellent client. She is requesting this loan for working capital that will be used to purchase raw materials such as corn, lime and a griddle. Her main wish is to improve her home; in this way she would be able to offer her daughters a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy corn, lime and a griddle

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 60 years old and married.  He is blessed with six children. He operates a retail shop together with his wife.  He left his former job as an Accounts clerk in a well known cement manufacturing company in East Africa (East Africa Portland Cements) and went into business so that he could get more income to support his big family.  

His business which is twelve years old has helped him to educate his six children, four of whom have finished school. Michael also does farming to supplement his income. He joined Ushindi Thiliu group in Faulu Kenya where he saves his money on a weekly basis.  He has also been able to service one loan through the group because he was guaranteed by the members. 

 He has requested a loan of 70,000 KES to add to his stock of basins, jars and utensils.  He hopes to develop his piece of land and to buy a pickup for transporting his stock in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of basins, jars and utensils

loans.name: Cate

texts.en: Cate is married with four children; two of her children go to school and the other ones are still young. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. Cate owns a restaurant in Kyebando market, selling all types of food. She wants to use this loan to buy more foodstuffs like bananas, rice, cassava and cooking utensils. She has been in this business for six years and her customers are her fellow market vendors. She works six days a week. Her business challenges include defaulters and ever-increasing prices of foodstuffs. She is aspiring to educate her children up to university level. She decided to work with MCDT because it was giving out loans to poor women who are in groups of five. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like bananas, cassava and cooking utensils

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Twenty-seven-year-old M. Mariam has subsisted on profits from her cold-drinks selling business for the last seven years. She started this business after she dropped out of school. Her cleanliness has won her laurels amongst her clients. It is for this reason that she has strengthened her niche as her customer base increases. She is thinking about opening up a restaurant. 

She is a divorced mother to one child and, in a week, she makes profits that add up to 100,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more cold drinks for her business.

loans.use: Purchase more soft drinks for her business

loans.name: Tolotea

texts.en:
Tolotea A. is 22 years old and single with one child.  She owns a business venture, planting and harvesting taro for sale.  She has three years of experience in this business.  

Tolotea needs a loan of 1,750 WST to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be about $125 per week) to improve the business.

In 2008, Tolotea joined SPBD and this is her 3rd loan with them.   SPBD's loans are Tolotea's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD:

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD, and since then it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. 

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Gulshan's Group

texts.en:
Gulshan lives in Lahore, a city famous for its culture. It is the second largest city in Pakistan and the capital of Punjab province. She is the mother of three children – two daughters and a son. Her older daughter is studying in 5th grade and her son is in 2nd grade, while her younger daughter is just 5 years old and has not started to attend school yet. 

Gulshan is living in a small two-room house where she moved after her marriage to D. H.. Her husband has a shop in the market where he sells milk and yogurt. His business is doing well and he is earning a good income. Gulshan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business.  This is her 3rd loan with Asasah, and she has proved to be a responsible lendee, never missing any meetings. She has applied for this loan because the holy month of Ramadan (the Muslim month of fasting) has started and the demand for milk and yogurt has almost tripled. In order to supply such a large quantity of milk and yogurt her husband needs to invest in his business. Gulshan is hopeful that with this investment her husband will be able to make the month of Ramadan very profitable.

loans.use: to purchase yogurt and milk for reselling

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen, the wife of M. A., lives in the city of Kasur, which is famous for its sweetmeats. Parveen and her family are involved in the manufacture and sale of shoes. They have all been doing this work for over seven years. Parveen, her husband and her daughter are most involved in this work. Her daughter is in 8th standard and, after coming back from school, she helps her parents make shoes.

The family makes shoes based on orders which they receive from the shoe shops. Their shoes are very famous among their customers. They love doing this work because it is the only work which gives them good earnings, allowing them to afford the basic necessities of life. Parveen has applied for a loan from Asasah in order to buy raw materials such as leather, glue, nails and shoe polishers in large quantities to maintain their business. Parveen and her family are hopeful that this business will make them successful and that they will soon open their own shoe shop where they will sell their shoes.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for their shoe making business

loans.name: Riham

texts.en:
Riham is a mother of three sons and two daughters, her husband is an electricity technician, he installs electricity networks for houses. One of Riham's sons works as a taxi driver in the city where they live. Riham has received three loans and this is the fourth one that her son needed to perform maintenance and pay for car licensing expenses.

Riham has been a very good customer who repays in time, and her son is a well-respected young man who wants to help his father raising his brothers and sisters and share in house expenses needs.

Riham's son Younis appears in the picture next to the car as Riham doesn't think it's appropriate that her picture is published online, especially she is not the one driving the car.

loans.use: Car Maintenance

loans.name: Johnita

texts.en:
Johnita D. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Sumaliring, Siaton, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: fish vending and food vending businesses. Her husband Obaldo D., who is 46 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 4 children who are 12 to 22 years old.

Johnita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Johnita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 which she intends to use to as additional working capital so that she could continue to save up for the future of her children's education and family. Johnita D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital.

loans.name: Maka

texts.en: Maka is 48 years old and married; her husband is a businessman. She has nine children, three of whom go to school.  Maka B. is currently in the business of making and selling ice cream.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more ingredients for her business.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for making ice cream to sell.

loans.name: Leandro Ariel

texts.es: El señor Leandro Ariel R. D. es trabajador de ESSO ON THE RUN se desempeña como Cajero desde hace 03 años es primer vez que solicita credito con CEPRODEL para compra de medicamentos que no le cubre el seguro social, vive con sus padres es soltero y no tiene hijos.
texts.en: Mr. Leandro Ariel R. D. has worked as a cashier at Esso On the Run for three years.  This is the first time that he is requesting a loan through CEPRODEL, and he is doing so in order to purchase medications that are not covered by social security.  He lives with his parents and he is single with no children.

loans.use: to buy medications that are not covered by social security

loans.name: San Antonio Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó gracias a las Señora Digna Rosa L. quien vive en el barrio San Miguel, de  la cuidad de Villarrica. Encantadas aceptaron conformar el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras nombrando al Comité.

 Las integrantes del comité en paralelo al trabajo que realizan en sus hogares se dedican a otras actividades como ser el comercio, que con el apoyo que le ofreció La Fundación lograron acrecentar sus ingresos, y por ende mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Ellas a través de este apoyo pudieron comprar artículos para la venta como bijouterie, medias, ropa interior, remeras, blusas, camisetas, etc. 
Manifiestan que están felices de poder integrar este grupo y poder de esa forma mejorar su nivel de vida y la de su familia. 
Asi la señora Digna L. quien se dedica a la venta de confecciones de ao po´i(artesania) que fabrican muchas de las señoras integrantes del comité.
Ella los adquiere a crédito y luego de vender le pagas a sus amigas y así se ayudan con las ventas. 
Son prendas de buenísima calidad y especial para la época de verano por que para esta temporada quiere estar prepara para sus clientes con suficientes mercaderías, para ello solicita el préstamo y de esa manera comprar como: camisas, vestidos, sabanas y otros.
texts.en:
This committee was established by Mrs Digna Rosa L. who lives in San Miguel neighborhood, in the city of Villarrica.  The group's members were delighted to form part of the 'Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras' (Committee of Enterprising Women).

The committee members, in parallel with the work that they carry out in their own homes, perform business activities such as buying and selling goods.  With the support offered to them by Fundación Paraguaya they have managed to increase their profits and thereby improve their quality of life.

The committee members, as a result of this support, have been able to buy articles to sell such as costume jewelry, tights, underwear, t-shirts, blouses and jerseys.

They state that they are happy to be able to form part of this group and, in this way, improve their standard of living and that of their families.

Mrs Digna L. sells clothes made from ao po'i (a fine cotton cloth which is traditional in this part of Paraguay).  Many of the other ladies in her committee make these clothes.

Digna acquires the clothes on credit and then, after she sells them, she pays her friends and they thereby help each other with the sales.  They are very good quality garments and special for the summer season.  She would like to be prepared for her customers this coming season and have enough merchandise.  For this reason, she is requesting this loan and hopes to use it to buy shirts, dresses, sheets and other products.

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as shirts, dresses, sheets, etc.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es: Patricia, de 32 años, es una madre de familia muy jovial, vive en su casa de sus padres, en compañía de su esposo y sus 2 hijos. El negocio al que patricia se dedica, es la compra y venta  de ropa casual mediante pedidos, que los  ofrece a sus amigos, familiares y vecinas de su barrio, quienes son sus asiduos compradores. Su cualidad y su buen y estilo hace que venda prendas exclusivas acorde a la temporada y más su buen trato, ayudan a que su negocio le sea muy rentable; y mas aún cuando capta más clientes. Por ello, acude a las galerías de “Gamarra”,  para abastecerse de más mercaderías. Lo que más le gusta de su negocio, es apreciar las tendencias de la moda y las conversaciones que tiene  con sus clientes. En adelante, piensa ampliar su negocio y espera encontrar un puesto en un mercado. Este es su primer crédito con MFP y sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo y lo hará, ya que desea contar con posteriores ayudas. Con el crédito que solicita, incrementará más prendas de vestir, para abastecer los pedidos pendientes que tiene.
texts.en: Patricia, a 32-year-old mother, is a very cheerful person. She lives in her parents' home in the company of her husband and her 2 children. Patricia's business is buying and selling casual clothing in response to orders. She offers her products to her friends, family members and neighbors in her area, who are her faithful customers. With her good sense for quality and style, she sells exclusive garments according to the season, and this, along with her excellent service, has helped her business become quite profitable for her, and even more so when she is able to attract new customers. For this purpose, she goes to the galleries of “Gamarra” to stock up on merchandise. What she likes best about her business is following fashion trends and having conversations with her customers. In the future, she is considering expanding her business, and she would like to find a space in a market. This is her first loan with MFP; she knows that she has to pay it off on time and she will do that, since she wants to qualify for more help in the future. With the loan she is requesting, she will expand her stock of garments so that she can fill her pending orders.

loans.use: Buying more garments to satisfy her customers' requests

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
María es una pequeña comerciante dedicada a trabajar. Madre de seis hijos. Su negocio es la venta de golosinas, helados y bisutería con once años trabajando. 
También cuenta con una entrada fija de alquiler de un cuarto. Su casa la ha venido mejorando con los préstamos que la institución ha dado, logro poner cerámica  a su casa, cambiar el techo y ahora seguirá dándole el toque final a su cocina con el piso y con la pintura para que quede en mejores condiciones. 
Para esto comprara los materiales necesarios para iniciar la obra. Feliz ya que cada día tiene una mejora a su vivienda. Gracias a los préstamos y apoyo de Afodenic que hace posible mejores vivienda a mujeres pobres en nuestro país.
texts.en:
María is a small businesswoman who is committed to working.  She has six children.  María's business is selling candies, ice cream and jewelry.  She has been doing this for eleven years.  María also has a fixed income from renting out a room.  She has been improving her home with loans from our institution.  She has managed to put down ceramic tiles in her home, replace her roof and now she will continue the work by providing some finishing touches to her kitchen, working on the floor and painting.  This will provide her with better conditions.

María will buy the materials that she needs to begin this work.  She is happy that there is a new improvement to her home every day, thanks to the loans and support from Afodenic that make housing improvements possible for poor women in our country.

loans.use: To buy building materials to finish her kitchen

loans.name: Jeanne Claire

texts.en:
Jeanne, 30, is married with two children aged two and ten. Her husband works as a teacher. She has had her business for about two years and currently employs six people. The hours of her business are from 5:30am to 9pm daily.

Jeanne has requested a Kiva loan in order to expand her restaurant by adding new offerings and developing the quantity and quality to satisfy her customers. With the additional profits from this loan, Jeanne will start saving, improve her family situation and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To expand her restaurant.

loans.name: Willian Wilfrido

texts.es:
Willian Wilfrido V. V., tiene 28 años, es casado, vive con su esposa en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos. Tiene 2 hijos. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C. TIERRA NUESTRA se encuentra ubicada en el recinto San Luís de Zapotal pertenece al Cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla de 14 miembros se dedica a las labores agrícolas en ciclo corto de siembra de maíz, arroz.

Willian Wilfrido se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y arroz. Compra sus productos en  Comercial Carlitos y vende en el mismo lugar.

Solicita el crédito para sembrar maíz, y arroz, compra de insumos y semillas. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es comprar una casa y un terreno.

Le gusta pasar con su familia.
texts.en:
Willian Wilfrido V. V., aged 28, is married and lives with his wife in the canton of Ventanas in the province of Los Ríos. He has two children.

The members of the rural communal bank Tierra Nuestra ("Our Land") meet on the grounds of San Luís de Zapotal in the canton of Ventanas. This group of 14 members works in agriculture in short-cycle sowing of corn and rice.

Willian Wilfrido is a farmer. He grows corn and rice. He buys his agricultural supplies at the market Comercial Carlitos and sells his products at the same place.

He applies for a loan to finance his sowing of corn and rice. He needs agricultural consumables and seeds. The loan will help him to pay for the required supplies. He faces challenges such as plagues, diseases and weather changes. His dream is to buy a house and a plot of land. He likes spending his free time with his family.

loans.use: To buy agricultural consumables and seeds

loans.name: Oyungerel

texts.en:
Oyungerel L. is 54, and a micro-entrepreneur. She lives with her daughter in an apartment, inherited from her mother, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. As a widow, she works extremely hard to provide for the daily needs of her family. 

She graduated from the Institute of Commerce and Business in Mongolia with a concentration in retail in 1977.  Until 2004, Oyungerel worked as a retail staffer for several local companies. 

Since 2005, Oyungerel has supported her family by operating a jewelry retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. She began her business by distributing silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets to local customers. Now her working capital is about 1.5 million MNT and its turnover is twice a month. She purchases her products from a Turkish jewelry wholesale supplier. 

Her moderate revenue supports her standard of living, though she would like to buy her own indoor jewelry store because the outdoor stall is difficult to work at due to weather conditions.  She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to invest in working capital before the Mongolian Lunar New Year holiday.  She believes that this loan and future loans will help her achieve her goal.  

Oyungerel’s biggest dream is to see her daughter to be successful in life and to help provide that opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Personal Expenses

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI sont mariés, ont une moyenne d’âge de 42  ans, et ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles polygames à Noumousso un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés se sont  bien dénoués. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de beurre de karité à l’image de NAHAWA K.  qui compte acheter avec son  prêt,  250kg de noix de karité pour les transformer en beurre.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Kadiolo les jours de foire et dans les villages environnants .
Le beurre de karité est  ensuite vendu au  grand marché de Kadiolo et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.250 FC CFA dont une partie est utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre partie épargnée pour le trousseau de sa fille. 
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en: The members of the group BENKADI are married and average 42 years of age and 5 children. They live in polygamous families in Noumousso, a district in Kadiolo City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on their sixth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. The past loans were all settled. This group of women does commerce in karité butter, as does Ms. Nahawa K., who intends to use her loan to buy 250 kg of karité nuts and process them into butter. The group members get their supplies at the main market in Kadiolo City on market days and from surrounding villages. The karité butter is then sold for cash to a customer base composed of women and men at the main market of Kadiolo and within the family. Nahawa envisions making an average monthly profit of 15,250 francs CFA. Part of the profits will be used to cover the loan interest, and the other part will be saved for her daughter’s hope chest. Her ambition is to increase her turnover, so as to satisfy her customers further.

loans.use: Buying karité nuts

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma P. is from the village of Casusan Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old. Norma is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Norma raises pigs to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over nineteen years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Norma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets and feeds. This will be her 3rd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Benno Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité BENNO est né le 04 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 07 femmes qui sont issues du même quartier. Elles sont nouées par des liens d'amitié et d'affinité. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de SANTHIABA SUD

Madame NDIAGNA D. (à droite de la photo avec une écharpe noir) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 49 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge des 06 enfants de sa jeune sœur 

Elle vend de la bouillie de mil. Elle achète le mil, le transforme en farine avant de le préparer en bouille. Elle vend également dans son quartier des tissus et des chaussures qu'elle achète à la capitale (Dakar)

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra de financer ses activité de vente de bouillie et de petit commerce.

Son objectif est de prendre en charge sa progéniture et ses neveux tout en renforçant son niveau d'épargne dans le Banc Villageois
texts.en:
The Benno solidarity group was created on 4th December 2007. It is made up of seven women who all come from the same neighborhood. They came together through friendship and affinity for one another. The group is part of the Banc Villageois in Santhiaba Sud. 

Mrs. Ndiagna D. (on the right of the photo in a black scarf) is in charge of the group. She is 49 years old, married and mother to three children. She also takes care of her young sister's six children. 

She sells "bouillie" (a type of gruel) made out of millet. She buys the millet and makes it into flour before preparing the "bouillie". She also sells fabric and shoes in her neighborhood; she buys these in the capital (Dakar). 

Her new loan will allow her to finance her sale of "bouillie" as well as her other trading business. 

Her aim is to provide for her children and her nephews while at the same time building up her savings in the Banc Villageois.

loans.use: to buy millet in order to make "bouillie", and also to buy fabric and shoes

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 39 years old and married with 6 children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Susan has a basket weaving business in the Philippines. Susan requested a 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase raw materials for her basket weaving business. Susan has been in this business for 11 years.

In the future, Susan would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for her basket weaving business

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: The strict-faced person shown in the picture is Kong S., aged 28, who lives in Dongkor commune. He spends most of his life working in the construction field as a building worker in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. From this job, he generates a profit of approximately $5 USD a day to help provide for his family’s daily expenses and provide more stability. His wife is a tailor who provides a sewing service to her neighbors. In order to make more income, Kong S. would like to use his loan to buy a boat to pick up passengers who wish to cross the river.

loans.use: to buy a boat to pick up passengers.

loans.name: Leonita

texts.en:
Leonita is 49 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Leonita is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Leonita has been raising pigs for two years and also earns additional income from fish vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Remilyn

texts.en:
Remilyn is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 31 years old. Remilyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Remilyn owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing, beauty items & shoe products from NATASHA, AVON & BOARDWALK in the local community. Remilyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Remilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Remilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Remilyn is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks like clothing, beauty supplies & shoes. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Remilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like clothing, beauty items & shoes.

loans.name: Benkadi  Viiii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi VIIII est composé de femmes mariées du village de NIAZEKAN de KIMPARANA relevant de SAN région de SÉGOU quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 41 ans et au moins 7 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide. Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 4 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur quatrième  prêt de campagne.
 TENE, compte utiliser son prêt utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, des petits équipements et des intrants pour mieux rentabiliser les récoltes. Les achats se font  au grand marché de KIMPARANA. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 23000 à 75000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi VIIII group consists of married women from the village of Niazekan in Kimparana, which belongs to the San region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the republic of Mali). They live in traditional families, are on average 41 years old and have at least seven children.

They grow peanuts. In order to make their farms profitable, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program four years ago. After having correctly repaid previous loans, they are now at their fourth farming loan.

Tene plans to use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanuts for planting, small equipment and inputs to ensure more profitable crops. Purchases are made in the grand market of Kimparana. After the rainy season, crops are stored for some time to maximize their value before being sold in the grand market of Kimparana and in the surrounding markets. Sales are retail and often wholesale, for cash to customers usually from large cities.

After selling their farm products each group member expects to make a profit between 23,000 and 75,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan and cover the families’ daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Nidal

texts.en:
Nidal is a 39-year-old father of seven sons. He has a grocery store in the city of Hebron while his wife is a DJ for women's parties as Hebron is one of the very conservative cities of Palestine.

Nidal took out a loan from FATEN to purchase a variety of items that are not available in all supermarkets in the city especially since there are many around him. More inventory will attract more customers and improve his income.

Nidal is photographed in the picture here.

loans.use: to purchase new items to sell in the store.

loans.name: Jimmy Alberto

texts.es:
El  señor  Jimmy Alberto vive en la ciudad de Managua, es una persona casada tiene a su cargo cuatro persona
Es padre  de familia de tres  menores trabaja en Managua  labora como agente de seguridad.
El señor  visito nuestra instalación para solicitar un crédito  ya que necesitaba el crédito para invertir en unas mejoras para su vivienda.
La inversión del crédito los va a utilizar para la compra de madera y zinc.
El señor Jimmy Alberto  agradece a ceprodel por el crédito que le dieron por que gracias al dinero financiado va a poder mejorar el techo de su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Mr. Jimmy Alberto lives in the city of Managua.  He is married and has four people under his care, including three minor children.  He works as a security agent in Managua.  He visited our offices to request a loan for home improvement.  He plans to use the loan to buy wood and zinc.

Jimmy Alberto is grateful to Ceprodel for the loan which will be used to improve the roof over his house.

loans.use: To buy construction materials.

loans.name: Cintya

texts.en: Cintya is 20 years old and lives in San Gabriel, Ecuador. She is married and lives with her husband and their two children, aged three years and two years, respectively. Cintya is a responsible and hardworking person who is very committed to her family. She is seeking this loan to increase her dairy business through the purchase of more milk cows to meet customer demand. She began working in her own business four years ago selling young bulls at every market in the province. She currently works with her parents and her husband. This is Cintya’s third loan from FODEMI. Her past loans have helped her improve her family’s quality of life, especially economically. Cintya’s dream is to continue with her business and eventually obtain her own dairy farm.

loans.use: to purchase dairy cows

loans.name: Niyamaddin

texts.ru: Niyamaddin jivet v Absheron regione. On ne jenat i ne imeyet detey. Niyamaddin 28 let. On etomu biznessu nauchilsya u svoyego otca. Uje 5 let kak on zanimayetsya pochinkoy mashin(tak je menyayet maslo tormazov, mashinnoye maslo, maslo matora i t.d)Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti i maslo dlya pochinki mashin i razvitiya svoyego biznessa.
texts.en: Niyamaddin lives in the Absheron region. He is single and has no children. Niyamaddin is 28 years old. He started this business with his father.  He has been working as a car mechanic for five years.  He also changes motor oil, break fluid, engine fluid, etc.  Now he needs 2000 AZN to buy parts and oil to repair cars and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy parts and oil to repair cars

loans.name: Hok

texts.en: Hok is a 47-year-old widow. She is a hardworking person who is providing for her family. She is the mother of three children and has been engaged in a lotus farming and fishing for years. She lives in Baray district, Kampong Thom province, Cambodia. Her son always wakes up in the dark, early morning to go fishing and comes back at the sun-raised time. He brings fish to her and she takes them to the local market everyday. Hok would like to get a loan of $300 to purchase a small fishing boat and boat machine. In the future, she hopes that her family can live in a bigger house and that she can send her children to the university.

loans.use: to purchase a small fishing boat and boat machine.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 30 years old and a married woman with eight children. All of her children are in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Buluk branch in Juba, South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Joyce requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She says that she will use the extra income from this loan to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is 31 years old and lives in Barnersville. He is married and has a 1 year old child at home. He is a high school graduate. For the past two  years, he has been selling soap, milk, batteries, toothpaste, and tissues in his community. He make a lot of profit, especially during the raining season. He is requesting a loan to purchase more soap, milk, batteries, toothpaste, and tissues for his business. He plans to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more soap, milk, batteries, toothpaste, and tissues for his retail business

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely is 43 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer, planting corn in the Philippines. The couple is doing their best to raise their standard of living. 
With a determination to earn income sufficient to sustain their daily household expenses, Fely is involved in a retail business which is a sari-sari (variety) store. While waiting for her customers to buy her products, Fely also runs a hog-raising business.
Now, Fely is happy that she already has six pigs to raise. She is asking for a loan of P50,000 to buy feed and vaccines of her pigs so that they can grow faster.

loans.use: to buy feed and vaccines of her pigs so that they can grow faster.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Elizabeth has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Elizabeth has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora Maria Guadalupe tiene ya más de ocho años dedicándose a la belleza personal de la mujer. 
Esta solicitando un préstamo para reparar y mejorar el local donde tiene su negocio desea acondicionar el local y ampliarlo tener mas espacio una sala de espera mas grade y cómoda, pintarla y comprar muebles mas moderno. No cuenta con el dinero para realizar esta inversión a su negocio. 
 Doña Maria Guadalupe es madre soltera, se hace cargo de sus tres hijas a las cuales les desea brindar lo mejor posible. 
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte de las ganancias que obtiene de su negocio ya que es la fuente de ingreso que tiene para ella y sus hijas.
texts.en:
Maria Guadalupe has had a women's beauty salon for more than 8 years.

She is requesting a loan to repair and improve her business premises.  She wants to renovate the place and expand it so that she can have more space, and a bigger and more comfortable waiting room.  She also wants to paint it and buy more modern furniture.  She doesn't have the money to make this investment in her business.  Maria Guadalupe is a single mother who is caring for 3 daughters, and she wants to provide for them as best she can. 

She plans to pay off the loan with a part of the earnings that she obtains from her business, since this is her source of income for herself and for her daughters.

loans.use: to make improvements to her beauty salon

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.es:
La señora Erlinda, tiene 53 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene 5 hijos entre las edades de 13 a 22  años,  en la actualidad 3 de sus hijos están estudiando, ella vive en una aldea rural del  Municipio de Santa Rita  Yoro, 
 Doña Erlinda trabaja a tiempo completo en su negocio de pulpería, donde se dedica a la compra y venta de productos lácteos, granos básicos y carnes.
Inicio su negocio con un prestamos de cuatro mil Lempiras (l.4,000.00) con el cual comenzó a vender  carne de pollo, en la actualidad ha logrado aumentar la oferta de otros productos.
Actualmente obtuvo su séptimo préstamo con ODEF por la cantidad de  L.16,000.00 el cual será invertido en la compra de productos lácteos y productos de la canasta básica familiar.
Ella se siente satisfecha porque considera que ODEF le tiene confianza al brindarle  oportunidades de financiamiento.
Su meta a futuro es mejorar las condiciones económicas de su hogar y continuar apoyando a sus hijos en la educación.
texts.en:
Erlinda, age 53, is a single mother.  She has five children between the ages of 13 and 22.  Three of her children are currently in school.  She lives in a rural village in the Santa Rita Yoro municipality.

Erlinda works full time in her business, a grocery store.  She buys and sells dairy products, basic grains, and meat.  She started her business with a loan for four thousand (4,000) lempiras, and she bought chicken.  She has currently managed to increase the number of products that she offers for sale.

She has now received her seventh loan with ODEF, and it is for 16,000 lempiras.  She will use the loan to buy dairy products and basic needs products.

She is pleased because ODEF trusts her by offering her financial opportunities.

Her goal for the future is to improve her household’s financial situation and to continue supporting her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy dairy products and basic needs products.

loans.name: Paulo

texts.en:
Paulo, age 27, has spent two years working hard to manage his retail shop business, which sells spare parts. He lives with his wife and child in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. 
 
To help expand his business, Paulo has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy spare parts for his shop, and this will help Paulo to generate greater profits, with which he intends to pay medical expenses, buy land, and build a house. Paulo hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business more. 

Paulo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Paulo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for resale

loans.name: Det

texts.en:
Mrs. Det, age 43, is a hard-working and responsible housewife who always cares for her family. Agriculture is her livelihood, from which she earns a profit of $2.00 each day. One of her daughters helps her earn income by working in a garment factory in Phnom Penh city, receiving a monthly salary of $100. 

Det has talked with her daughter and she decided that she will create a fruit selling business from a rented booth in front of the garment factory. This new project will need capital of around $500 to start, yet she doesn’t have enough money. Thus, she is taking out a loan from HKL and Kiva to pay for a rented booth and to purchase a stock of fruit to sell. She hopes to sell out all her fruit and to grow this business in the future.

loans.use: to pay for a rented booth and to purchase a stock of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Karapet

texts.en:
Karapet is from the village of Balkho, South Georgia. He is 49 years old and lives in the village with his family: his wife Tamara, two sons who are 19 and 18 years old, an 11-year-old daughter, and his 85-year-old mother. His children go to school. 

Karapet and Tamara manage the agricultural business of the family. In particular, they have milk cows and produce cheese, which is sold at the local market. Also, the family grows potatoes on a family-owned plot of land. The potatoes are also sold locally. 

Karapet requested credit for purchasing a house in his village. The house will be used by Karapet’s sons when they marry. The family's existing house is too small and can’t hold more people.

loans.use: to purchase a house in the village.

loans.name: For Better Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “For Better” group from Lunsar, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are small businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to seek for a loan of 500,000 SLL for each member in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profits, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ya Sinna. Ya Sinna was born in Lunsar about thirty-six years ago. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a lorry driver and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. Ya Sinna has been a businesswoman for fifteen years now. She sells market food. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy palm oil, onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, rice, and other items.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, and rice

loans.name: Fizatou

texts.fr:
Fizatou est une femme âgée de 36 ans. Elle est mariée å un chauffeur. Elle a 3 enfants qui vont tous à l’école. Le premier a dix ans et le dernier a six ans.
Fizatou travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2000. Elle vend des pagnes pour tous clients de façon ambulante. Elle achète les produits à Lomé. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, elle n’a las de difficultés.
Fizatou a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des pagnes. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité.
Dans les prochaines années, Fizatou voudrait agrandir son activité en ouvrant une boutique. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit d’assurer le bien être de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fizatou is a 36 year-old woman. She is married to a driver. She has three children who all attend school. The oldest is 10 and the youngest is 6.
Fizatou has worked has a retailer since 2000. She sells pagnes (colorful West African cloth) to customers at their homes. She buys her products in Lome. She works alone and doesn't have any major challenges at this time.
Fizatou has requested her third loan from WAGES to buy pagnes. She wants to reinvest in the business.
In the coming years, Fizatou would like to grow the business and open a small shop. She intends to ensure the well-being of her family with the profits from her business.

loans.use: to purchase pagnes (colorful West African cloth).

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 52 years old, married and has 6 children. 3 of the children are in school.

Jocelyn is in the agricultural business farming sugarcane in the Philippines. Jocelyn requested a 22,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Jocelyn has been farming sugarcane for 10 years now and has borrowed 13 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Jocelyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Gladis Argentina

texts.es:
La  señora Gladis de 58 años de edad, es madre soltera, vive con sus cuatro hijos en su casa de habitación ubicada en una aldea de San Lorenzo, Valle al sur de Honduras, su negocio es la elaboración y venta de pan.
Doña Gladis se dedica desde hace  ya varios años a la elaboración y venta de pan se levanta desde muy temprano todo los días a fabricar el pan para luego viajar al mercado viejo y nuevo con la ayuda de sus dos hijas quienes son sus empleadas, Ella solicita el préstamo para compra de harina, leña y otros productos que son la materia prima para elaborar su pan.
Doña Gladis con las ganancias de su negocio  y con el apoyo de este préstamo desea continuar en el proyecto de su casa que esta construyendo, y esta contenta por el apoyo de PRISMA a su patrimonio ya que con los préstamo recibidos a avanzado en la construcción de su casa.
Su sueño es que su familia tenga una vivienda digna donde puedan vivir.
San Lorenzo, Honduras - Abril del 2012

loans.use: Para la compra de harina, leña y otros productos para su negocio

loans.name: Las Flores Group

texts.es:
La señora Elena está casada, tiene 36 años de edad, cursó solamente un año en la escuela primaria, tiene 1 hijos el cual esta estudiando, se dedica al comercio de ropa típica, inicio este negocio con la expectativa de tener un trabajo y hasta el momento lleva 10 años de experiencia, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposa quien se dedica al mismo trabajo.

Organiza un grupo para poder solicitar un préstamo que lo utilizara para la compra de ropa para señorita y poder así mejorar, su negocio y sus ventas, espera tener más capital y un local propio para su venta. Las demás integrantes del grupo se dedican a comercio, venta de ropa, tortillas, refacciones y una de ella se dedica a la elaboración de dulces al horno.

loans.use: Comprar mercadería

loans.name: Lucetta

texts.en:
Lucetta has been in active farming for fifteen years in Central Kenya. She currently produces maize, tobacco, beans and green peas, which she sells to the local market to meet her family's daily needs. Lucetta gets additional income from her motorcycle transport business. She is married and has four children aged between 5 and 20 years.

Lucetta has made a loan request of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds. She says the income from the poultry business will help improve her family's living standards. Lucetta also plans to run a cereals retail business. She notes that her major challenges come from pests, animal diseases and limited rains.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: María

texts.en:
Maria moved to Guayaquil from Cotopaxi in search of a better life. Although it was difficult to leave her family she felt that she could only provide a better future for her kids if she moved away. When she arrived to Guayaquil things were not too much better though. She lives in one of the worst sectors of the city but she is trying to move forward.

She runs a smalls shop where she sells snacks and other foods. She wants to invest in her store by buying new shelves and purchasing her products in bulk. With the extra profits she will improve her home.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Buy new shelves and products

loans.name: Tang

texts.en:
Tang is 38 years old. He had his wife, Ha, have 4 children between 14 and 5. Tang suffers from chronic bronchitis and cannot do much strenuous work. Their 2 youngest children are epileptic: Tang and Ha had to sell a piece of land to pay for the numerous medical visits and treatments. But the children are better now.

Tang's family has only a small hut and a little more than 1 hectare of agriculture land. The land is poor and they have no capital, so they lend it out to a neighbor.

Tang has repaid his first loan of $50. He became free from the local moneylender and increased his daily profit from just 75 cents to $1 now. He wants to borrow for another cycle of 7 months. His long-term dream is to plant cashew trees on their land.

loans.use: Small waste recycling business

loans.name: Nji Ignatius

texts.en:
Born in 1974, Ignatius is married and has three children. He faces difficulties in taking care of his family, especially the wife who gave birth through surgical operation for all three children. His father died when he was only a child, and there was nobody to support him through secondary education. Motivated by these setbacks, he became a member of GHAPE and benefited from his first loan of $30 in 1998. Throughout the period of 1998 to April 2007, he has proven his ability to receive, invest, and repay loans up to $400. With these loans, he has assisted the community with good piglets, manure, and food crops.

Given a loan of $1000, he plans to buy a motorcycle and the official documents. Since the roads are not in good condition, many transport vehicles hardly go through the road, and motorcycles are the only alternatives to transport people and luggage.

He plans to pay his loan in 24 months. The first loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase of Motorcycle

loans.name: Irina

texts.en: Irina helps to support her family with a small business - she sells socks and women’s hosiery at a busy market in Melitopol, Ukraine. She and her husband, Michail, have two sons. Irina started her business ten years ago, about a year after her second son was born. The business has been an important source of income for the family. Currently, Irina makes around US$340 in net profit per month. Irina has been a great client with Nadiya Ukraine and has been able to take out several loans that have helped with the development of her business. Her future plans include opening an additional sales location which would boost her income. Irina has requested a short-term loan of US$450 to help purchase additional inventory for her clothing retail business.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Millet processing machine

loans.name: Jose Martir

texts.es:
I have made a living selling fruit for 7 years. I make my sales by traveling around with my old little cart. I cover several neighborhoods where I have my steady customers. I need this money to buy various fruits because I have several orders for apples and grapes. I also have responsibilities like my family, my wife, and a son, who is studying in elementary school. I hope to give the best education I can to my son. The money is very urgent for me right now, and I am very grateful for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Yo me ddico a la venta de frutas hace 7 años. Las venta las hago ambulante en mi carrito viejo. Yo recorro varias colonias donde tengo mis clientes fijos. El dinero lo necesito para comprar varias frutas porque tengo pedidos de manzanas y uvas. Tambien tengo varios responzabilidad con mi familia, miesposa y un hijo que lo tengo estudiando en la escula, yo deseo darle lo mejor a mi hijo que con sus estudios. En estos momentos me urge el dinero, les agradesco mucho por su ayuda.

loans.use: Purchase of fruits like watermelons, oranges, bananas, papayas, apples, and grapes.

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en:
Mr. S. Sambo has been married since 1985 and has four childre:three sons and one daughter. He fishes his small and old boat along the river within the district. He plans to expand his fishing business by purchasing a new boat and equiping it with a motor. His wife, Mrs. Ry Srey, is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1980 and began her own silk production in the same year. She also farms in the village.

Mr S. has borrowed money from MAXIMA thrice already. Now he is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a boat, machine and fishing net and to expand his wife's silk production.

loans.use:
To purchase a boat, machine and fishing net and to expand 
silk production

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael T. is married and a father of four children. He runs his business with his wife and their dream is to provide their children with the best possible education. Mr. T. has been accessing credit from SMT for the last 3 years.  He used his previous loans to rent a venue for his pub business and he is now planning to expand of the business.  He is therefore requesting a loan of $1,000 for capital investment.

loans.use: Generate higher profits by offering more products to attract new customers.

loans.name: Lugoba A 2021(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sarah Nambasa. She is currently in the business of tailoring and selling clothes and is requesting a loan of UGX 900,000 to buy more cloth materials. Sarah is a 40 year old widow with 6 children ranging from age 8 to 24, all of whom go to school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX 45,000 in profit and combined with the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for the family's basic needs.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Joan A., Juliet M., Deborah N., and Farida N.. Joan A. is currently in the business of selling fresh foods and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to increase her stock.

Juliet M. is currently in the business of running a salon and is requesting a loan of UGX 700,000 to buy more hair oil.

Deborah N. is currently in the business of selling used clothing and is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to add more stock.

Farida N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to buy a fridge and more shop items.

loans.use: To buy more cloth materials and fabrics

loans.name: Victory Nabingo A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Agnes L.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine. Agnes is 44 years old and is single. She has 1 child aged 25. Each week, Agnes makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her tailoring business. Agnes has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Agnes is joined in her small group by Getrude N., Rose N., Mayi M., and Justine N.. Getrude N. has a business running a bar and wants to purchase a fridge. Rose N. is currently operating a market stall business and wants a loan to add stock. Mayi M. operates a clinic business and wants to purchase more drugs. Justine N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to put in more shelves.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: America Miriam

texts.es:
Mrs. America Miriam R. E. is thirty-three years old and has an elementary education only. She has two dependent children. She lives in the village of Bellavista in the Salpo district of Otuzco province in La Libertad, Perú.

Mrs. America has set up a spot in her home where she runs a general store and sells basic necessities, soda, candy, and beer. She also has a small bakery where she makes sweets, biscuits, and bread. She carries her products to the city of Trujillo in a truck that she rents.

She began her business by making bread, and she started her general store with very few products, which she has increased over time.

She is a member of the communal bank "Working Woman," from whom she obtained her first loan for $100. With this money, she bought the goods she needed to stock her store.

With this loan for $375, which she will repay in four months, she will buy two sacks of rice, two bags of sugar and a case of oil to stock her store, and to make bread she will buy a sack of flour, butter, yeast, and firewood.

She is a member of social project, Vaso de Leche ("Glass of Milk") "Maria Parado de Bellido.", a program similar to food stamps that provides food to vulnerable citizens in Peru. Her greatest dream is to build a home in the city of Trujillo and start a business there.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora America Miriam R. E. tiene 33 años de edad, estudio solo educación primaria. Tiene dos hijos que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el centro poblado menor de Bellavista en el distrito de Salpo en la provincia de Otuzco departamento La Libertad – Perú. La señora America ha ambientado un lugar en su casa para colocar una bodega en la que vende productos de primera necesidad, gaseosas, golosinas y cerveza. Además tiene una pequeña panadería en el que elabora dulces, bizcocho y pan. Los productos le traen desde la ciudad de Trujillo en un camión el cual tiene contrato. Su negocio inicia con la elaboración de pan, con su bodega se inicio no hace mucho con pocos productos, con el tiempo irá incrementando. Ella integra el Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajadoras” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compro todo lo necesario para surtir su bodega. Con el préstamo de S/.1000.00 el cual cancelara en cuatro meses comprará dos sacos de arroz, dos bolsas de azúcar y una caja de aceite para surtir su tienda y para la elaboración del pan comprará un saco de harina, manteca, levadura y leña.. Es socia del programa vaso de leche “Maria Parado de Bellido”. Su mayor sueño es construir una casa en la ciudad de Trujillo y allí instalar un negocio.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for her general store and ingredients for her bakery

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena, age 29, is married with a four-year-old. She makes a living by selling clothing, and also has a mill which she charges usage for. She started these businesses last year. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm and is able to make a monthly profit of about $90.

Zena hopes for a loan to purchase more clothing to sell. She is a member of the loan group, Tupendane. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim is the wife of N. M., who is 54 years old. Shamim and her family live in a small city named Arifwala, Pakistan. Shamim owns a two room brick house, and she is a mother of two sons. She successfully completed her frist loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute of Pakistan. Her husband is a mason by profession, and she is applying for a loan for her husband, who wants to buy the masonry tools to expand his business.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members who are: Gulzaran baji (Baji is a term meaning "elder sister" in Urdu) wants a loan for her fruit business; Amna baji wants a loan for her fruit business; Sharifan baji wants a loan for her wood business; and Kosar baji wants a loan to buy electronic items for her husband’s electric shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony E. is 44 years old and is married with 8 children. He lives in Benin City, Nigeria. He buys second-hand car batteries, repairs them, and sells them to people who cannot afford new car batteries. The demand for second-hand batteries is high.

Anthony is requesting a loan of $1, 200 USD to meet the demands of his customers. He is a LAPO client.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand car batteries to sell

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap T. is a farmer in Prey Totoeng Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a grocer also. Her husband, Mr. Vanna Heam, is a farmer. Also, he uses his motorbike to carry a cart for carrying passengers and goods to earn more. (Pictured are Mrs. Sopheap T. and her husband, Mr. Vanna Hearn.)

Mrs. Sopheap T. is 30 years old and has three children. One child attends school, however, the others are too young to work or enroll school. Mrs. Sopheap T. now faces an obstacle, because she does not have enough animals to plow her field. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy a second cow to use as a draft animal. Previously, Mrs. Sopheap T. had a loan from AMK to buy a cart in order to start her husband's business, and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: Buy a second cow to use as draft animal for plowing

loans.name: Yean

texts.en:
Mrs. Yean C., 60, and her husband, Mr. Tha Khat, 70, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1964 and have seven children: three sons and four daughters. Two of their sons are married and living in separate houses, and the other son is a tailor. Their four daughters are silk weavers.

Mrs. Yean has been a weaver since 1964, employing a skill she learned from her sister-in-law. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Tha is a farmer. He grows rice and sesame in the farm near the house.

Yean is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase silk materials for her three daughters' weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Almira

texts.en:
Almira R., born in 1980, is married and has two children, one four years old and the other two. Her husband is the income earner in the household because Almira is not employed. However, in addition to taking care of her home and children, she keeps busy in her little garden producing vegetables for the family’s consumption.

She also has a corn field and this autumn will have enough corn to begin raising poultry, an endeavor for which Almira is requesting a loan of $450. She hopes to thereby raise the family income and provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: To buy poultry.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
Con más de 20 años en el negocio de la crianza de chanchos, la señora Dominga, de 54 años,  también vende menúes afuera de un colegio de su barrio. Con sus 5 hijos ya mayores, ella se encarga de su nieta mayor, en edad escolar. A la señora no le han pasado los años en vano y el día a día, en la crianza de chanchos, se le hace más difícil, sin embargo, ella no declina y su mirada se mantiene optimista con respecto al porvenir que quiere trazarle a su nieta.
Para tan ardua labor necesita de 800 soles de préstamo, en aras de cubrir los gastos que le depararían la compra de alimentos para sus animales y la elaboración de las comidas que expende.
texts.en:
With more than 20 years' experience raising pork, Dominga, aged 54 years, also occupies her time selling foods outside a school in her neighbourhood. Her five children are now of age, but she takes care of her eldest granddaughter who is still schoolaged. To her the years have not been passed in vain, and her day to day chores raising livestock is getting harder. But nontheless, she never gives up and her outlook remains optimistic in providing for her granddaughter.

For her hard work, she requires a loan amounting to 800 soles, with which she will cover the expenses she will encounter when purchasing feed for her animals, and for the production of foods that she sells.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pork to make them ready for sale at Christmas and to purchase the necessary ingredients for the her food sales.

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en: Agatha B. sells groceries like biscuits, sugar, Milo, milk and other items at Adakope near Shama. Agatha has received junior high education. She is a single parent and has three children. Agatha has been selling groceries since 1998. She is responsible for providing the basic needs of the family. Her loan will be used as an additional capital to increase the sale of groceries. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest for the expansion of the business.

loans.use: Agatha would like to increase the sale of groceries.

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi O. sells provisions and drinks. The demands for her provisions and drinks are high. She started this business in 2000. Ngozi needs a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. Ngozi says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mr. Pech Kek Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eighteen people in Chamka village in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia, have formed a village bank loan group and Mr. Pech K. is the village bank president. He is a rice middleman who buys rice to hold in inventory and re-sell later at a better price. His wife, Mrs. P. Phally, is a successful pig breeder and she wants to expand her business. Thus, Mr. Pech K. decided to request a loan to buy three more piglets for breeding. He hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. He is 42 years old and the father of three children who are enrolled in the local school.

All the members in this group loan will receive End-of-Term loans.  In EoT loans, payment on principal is not required until the very end of the loan term but is allowed at any time that the borrower is able to make such a payment. The EoT loan is AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. Most clients start to make principal payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy three piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Crecer Group

texts.es: El grupo "Crecer" esta representado por la señora Rossy y conformado por 17 miembros los cuales vienen cursando su primer ciclo dentro D. la fundación agrocapital. Los socios (as) se dedican a actividades D. índole comercial vendiendo productos como el pan, la comida y ofreciendo cosméticos por catalogo, otros se dedican a la prestación se servicios como el trasporte, la agricultura y el servicio domestico. Siempre existe la competencia D. productos por la oferta y la demanda pero los integrantes del grupo saben como salir adelante para poder llevar el pan D. cada día a sus hogares. El destino del financiamiento es para la compra D. productos, insumos y materiales para poder brindar un mejor servido y mejor sus ingresos para dar a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida. Las socias cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios debido a que ya trabajaron con instituciones similares a la fundación agrocapital, por lo tanto responderán con responsabilidad y cumplimiento con sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
The 'Crecer' group is represented by Rossy and is maD. up of 17 members who are entering into their first loan cycle with Fundacion Agrocapital. The members work in a range of commercial activities including selling bread, food, and cosmetics by catalogue. Others work in the service sector including transport, farming and domestic services. There is always competition in the supply and demand for products, but the group members know how to move forward and meet the daily needs of their households. The loan will be used to buy products, basic supplies and materials, in order to offer better service and increase their incomes, and in such a way offer their families a better quality of life. The members have experience in solidarity groups as they have previously worked with organizations similar to Fundacion Agrocapital. For this reason they will respond responsibly and fulfil their obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris Y. is thirty years old. She is a married woman with three children, all of whom are boys. She says all of her sons are in the basic school. Doris’ husband is a carpenter and a cocoa farmer. She lives with her husband and the children in a rented apartment in Berekum in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Berekum is a busy business centre which is about twenty-five minutes' drive from Sunyani, the regional capital.

Doris enjoys selling foodstufs. She sells maize and dried pepper. She procures bags of maize and the dried pepper directly from the farmers in the surrounding villages where it is cost-effective. Doris treks to other markets to sell her goods, mostly to food vendors. She says retailers also come to buy from her.

Doris has been in business for seven years. She wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can procure bags of maize in bulk and pepper in bulk.

loans.use: To procure maize and dried pepper in bulk

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is forty-three-year-old Salma M. from Mwanza. She is married with five children, between the ages of eight and eighteen. She is also responsible for supporting a young girl who is an orphan. 

Salma has been running a poultry business since 2004. In her business she sells chickens as well as eggs. She works at the business for four hours a day, seven days a week with the assistance of two employees. Salma currently earns about $500 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 to buy more chicks which she will raise and resell. In the future, she plans to open another business. Salma thanks you for supporting her!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, so they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their business equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, which enables them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more chicks to raise and resell

loans.name: Akeem

texts.en: Akeem A. is 33 years old and married with two children.  He sells industrial pipes that are used for transporting water from bore holes and taps to tanks for building and domestic uses.  He is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more industrial pipes to sell.  He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more pipes to sell.

loans.name: Tootoo

texts.en: Tootoo , 50, is married with 5 children.  She has 5 year(s) of experience in the bakery  business. She sells to the villagers/public 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala .  SPBD loans are Tootoo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase bag of flour, sugar, frying pan, whipping cream, cooking oil and plastic bags

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is 37 years old and married with four children. He makes laundry detergent to sell. He is requesting for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more laundry detergent materials. He says thanks to kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more laundry detergent materials

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene O. is from Dipolog City. She is 36 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Arlene has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Arlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials for the repair of their residential house. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Arlene from PMPC. She plans to have a comfortable shelter for her three kids.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for house repair

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy M. is from the village of Gusa , Cagayan de Oro City. She is a 31-year-old married mother of two school-aged children. To make a living, Nancy owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling of used clothing locally known as ukay-ukay.
